column3: When to Release the Sprint Button in FIFA
column5:
As a professional FIFA player, knowing when to release the sprint button is crucial for maintaining control, conserving player stamina, and executing effective gameplay strategies. Here are key recommendations on when to release the sprint button during matches:

1. Maintaining Control and Dribbling

  • Close Control: Release the sprint button when dribbling in tight spaces or when closely marked by opponents. This allows your player to maintain better control of the ball, execute quick turns, and perform skill moves effectively.

  • Change of Direction: Before making sharp changes in direction or performing skill moves, release the sprint button to ensure your player responds accurately to your inputs without losing balance or overrunning the ball.

2. Passing and Positioning

  • Pass Accuracy: Release sprint before making passes to improve passing accuracy and reduce the likelihood of misplacing the ball. Players are more stable and make better decisions when not sprinting.

  • Positioning: When positioning your players offensively or defensively, release sprint to maintain optimal positioning and readiness to react to changes in the game situation.
column7:
3. Defending and Tactical Awareness

  • Defensive Stability: Release sprint while defending to maintain defensive stability and control. It allows you to stay balanced, anticipate opponent movements, and make timely tackles or interceptions.

  • Anticipating Play: Before anticipating passes or through balls from opponents, release sprint to ensure your player is ready to react quickly and intercept or close down space effectively.

4. Conserving Stamina

  • Longevity: Continuous sprinting drains player stamina rapidly. Release the sprint button during less critical moments of the game to conserve stamina for crucial phases, such as counter-attacks or defensive transitions.

  • Endurance Management: In longer matches or during extra time, managing player stamina becomes vital. Release sprint periodically to maintain player endurance throughout the match duration.

5. Executing Tactical Strategies

  • Game Management: Depending on the match situation (leading, trailing, or tied), release sprint to adapt to tactical changes and manage the tempo of the game effectively.

  • Team Coordination: Coordinate with teammates by releasing sprint to maintain positional discipline and execute team strategies, such as pressing or maintaining possession.

6. Skill Moves and Finishing

  • Skill Execution: Release sprint before executing skill moves to ensure precise execution and maintain control of the ball during dribbling sequences.

  • Shooting Accuracy: When approaching the goal for a shot, release sprint to improve shooting accuracy and increase the likelihood of scoring goals.

Conclusion

Knowing when to release the sprint button in FIFA enhances your overall gameplay by improving control, conserving player stamina, and executing tactical strategies effectively. By incorporating these professional recommendations into your gameplay strategy, you can optimize player performance, maintain tactical discipline, and achieve better results on the virtual pitch. Mastering the art of releasing the sprint button at the right moments distinguishes top-tier FIFA players and contributes to success in competitive play.

column3: Basics of Defense in FIFA
column5:
Defense is a fundamental aspect of FIFA gameplay that requires tactical awareness, timing, and effective player positioning. Whether you're new to the game or looking to refine your defensive skills, mastering these basics will help you become a more formidable defender:

1. Player Selection and Switching

  • Manual Control: Use the right analog stick (RS) or player switching button (L1/LB) to select the nearest defender to the ball carrier.

  • Anticipation: Anticipate your opponent's movements and switch to the defender closest to their intended path or receiving player.

2. Positioning and Formation

  • Maintain Shape: Position defenders to maintain the team's defensive shape, which varies depending on your chosen formation (e.g., 4-4-2, 4-3-3).

  • Covering Space: Cover passing lanes and potential areas of attack by positioning defenders strategically between attackers and the goal.

3. Tackling and Interceptions

  • Timing Tackles: Use the standing tackle (Circle/B) or slide tackle (Square/X) buttons judiciously to dispossess opponents.

  • Interceptions: Use the intercept (X/A) button to cut passing lanes and anticipate opponent passes, preventing attacks before they develop.
column7:
4. Jockeying and Containment

  • Jockeying: Use the L2/LT button to jockey (stay close to) the opponent without diving into tackles prematurely.

  • Containment: Hold the contain button (X/A) to maintain pressure on the ball carrier while waiting for the right moment to tackle or force an error.

5. Defensive Awareness and Tracking Runs

  • Awareness: Stay aware of off-ball movement by attackers and track their runs to prevent them from getting behind your defensive line.

  • Communication: Coordinate with AI defenders by adjusting defensive tactics (e.g., team pressing, defensive line) using the D-pad to adapt to the game situation.

6. Clearances and Goalkeeping

  • Clearances: Use the clearance button (Circle/B) to safely remove the ball from dangerous areas, especially when under pressure near your own goal.

  • Goalkeeper Control: Utilize goalkeeper movement (Right Stick) to position the goalkeeper effectively and narrow down shooting angles during one-on-one situations.

7. Avoiding Mistakes and Patience

  • Avoid Overcommitting: Avoid committing too many defenders forward, which can leave gaps in defense and expose you to counter-attacks.

  • Patience: Be patient in defense, especially when facing skilled attackers. Avoid rushing tackles and focus on forcing opponents into making mistakes.

Conclusion

Mastering the basics of defense in FIFA involves understanding player selection, positioning, tackling techniques, defensive awareness, and goalkeeper control. By practicing these fundamentals and adapting them to different game situations, you can effectively neutralize opponent attacks and build a solid defensive foundation for success in matches. Remember, defense is not just about individual skills but also about teamwork and tactical discipline, which are essential for achieving consistent results on the virtual pitch.

column3: Basics of Attacking in FIFA
column5:
Attacking in FIFA requires a blend of creativity, strategy, and precision to break down defenses and score goals effectively. Whether you're new to the game or aiming to refine your attacking skills, mastering these basics will help you become a more potent offensive force:

1. Player Movement and Positioning

  • Off the Ball Movement: Use the left analog stick to move players into open spaces, create passing lanes, and make runs behind the defense.

  • Positional Awareness: Anticipate and exploit gaps in the opponent's defense by positioning your players strategically. Adjust your formation and tactics (e.g., width and depth) to support your attacking style.

2. Passing and Build-Up Play

  • Short Passes: Use short, precise passes (X/A button) to maintain possession, move the ball around the pitch, and create passing triangles to advance towards the opponent's goal.

  • Through Balls: Execute through balls (Triangle/Y button) to send teammates into space behind the defense. Time these passes well to beat the offside trap and create goal-scoring opportunities.
column7:
3. Dribbling and Skill Moves

  • Basic Dribbling: Use close control (R2/RT button) to shield the ball from defenders and maintain possession in tight spaces.

  • Skill Moves: Master basic skill moves (Right Stick) such as step-overs, ball rolls, and drag-backs to beat defenders and create shooting opportunities.

4. Shooting and Finishing

  • Shot Types: Experiment with different shot techniques (Circle/B button) such as finesse shots, power shots, and chip shots depending on the situation and the goalkeeper's positioning.

  • Placement: Aim for the corners of the goal to increase the chances of scoring. Adjust shot power using the shot meter for optimal accuracy and power.

5. Crossing and Headers

  • Crossing: Use crossing (Square/X button) to deliver accurate crosses into the penalty area for your teammates to attack.

  • Headers: Time headers (Circle/B button) accurately to direct the ball towards goal. Utilize players with good heading attributes and positioning to capitalize on crossing opportunities.

6. Patience and Game Management

  • Build-Up Play: Be patient in your build-up play, especially against defensively organized opponents. Look for openings and avoid forcing risky passes or shots.

  • Game Tempo: Control the game tempo by varying your attacking approach. Switch between quick counter-attacks and patient possession-based play to keep opponents guessing.

7. Set Pieces

  • Free Kicks: Learn different free-kick techniques (L1/LB button) for direct shots or crosses into the box. Practice to master curve and power for effective free-kick execution.

  • Corner Kicks: Use corner kicks to create scoring opportunities. Adjust corner kick tactics (D-pad) and aim for teammates making runs into the box.

Conclusion

Mastering the basics of attacking in FIFA involves understanding player movement, passing, dribbling, shooting techniques, and set-piece strategies. By practicing these fundamentals and adapting them to different match situations, you can unlock your team's offensive potential and score more goals consistently. Experiment with various attacking styles, learn from your gameplay experiences, and refine your skills to become a more formidable attacking force in FIFA.

column3: Importance of Keeping the Ball and Attacking in the 45th and 90th Minutes in FIFA

    • Game Dynamics: FIFA's game mechanics sometimes favor action or goals during added time periods. Being proactive in these moments can lead to scoring opportunities that may not have been as prominent during regular play.

    • Wasting Time: If you have a lead, maintaining possession near the end of each half can help run down the clock and secure the result without risking turnovers that could lead to equalizers or turnarounds.

  • Tactical Flexibility: Coaches often make strategic substitutions just before halftime or full-time to reinforce their team's performance. Utilizing fresh legs or adjusting tactics during these intervals can strengthen your team's ability to control the game.

  • Opponent Awareness: Assessing your opponent's gameplay tendencies and adjusting your strategy accordingly before the end of each half can give you a competitive edge in anticipating and countering their moves.

  • Opportunities for Goals: Set pieces, such as free kicks and corners, are more frequent in added time situations. Being adept at executing these plays can increase your chances of scoring critical goals before the whistle blows.

  • Decisive Moments: Matches can often be decided by goals scored or conceded in added time periods. Being proactive and assertive in attacking or defending during the 45th and 90th minutes can tip the balance in your favor and secure crucial wins or draws.

  • Pressure Situations: The pressure of added time can affect player performance and decision-making. Maintaining composure and executing game plans effectively during these moments are key to achieving positive results in FIFA matches.

Conclusion

In FIFA, the importance of keeping possession and attacking in the 45th and 90th minutes cannot be overstated. These periods present opportunities to influence momentum, manage the game effectively, capitalize on scoring chances, and secure favorable outcomes. By recognizing the significance of these critical moments and strategically approaching gameplay during added time intervals, you can elevate your performance and enhance your success in FIFA matches.

• Feints and skill moves in FIFA can be game-changers, allowing you to beat defenders, create scoring opportunities, and ultimately secure victories. Here are three highly effective feints and skill moves that can help you win matches:

    1. La Croqueta

    • Execution: Perform La Croqueta by flicking the right stick (RS) left and right (or right and left) while dribbling. This move allows your player to quickly shift the ball from one foot to the other, evading defenders.

    • Effectiveness: La Croqueta is particularly effective for quickly changing direction and accelerating past defenders, especially in tight spaces near the opponent's penalty area.

    • Application: Use La Croqueta when approaching defenders at an angle or when you need to create space for a shot or pass. It's effective against both AI defenders and human opponents.
column7:
2. Elastico

  • Execution: Execute the Elastico by flicking the right stick (RS) forward and then quickly to the left or right (depending on the direction you want to move) in a quarter-circle motion.

  • Effectiveness: The Elastico is a flashy and effective skill move that can deceive defenders by swiftly changing direction. It's great for accelerating past opponents and creating one-on-one opportunities.

  • Application: Use the Elastico when dribbling down the wing or when cutting inside from wide positions. It's effective against defenders who are anticipating a straightforward dribble.

3. Drag Back

  • Execution: Perform a Drag Back by holding the right stick (RS) in the opposite direction of your player's movement while dribbling. This move allows your player to pull the ball back quickly and change direction.

  • Effectiveness: The Drag Back is excellent for creating space in crowded areas and evading tight marking. It's a simple yet effective skill move that can catch defenders off guard.

  • Application: Use the Drag Back when you're under pressure from defenders or when you need to quickly change direction to escape marking. It's effective in midfield battles and around the penalty area.

Tips for Using Feints Effectively:

  • Practice: Spend time in skill games or offline matches to practice these feints until you can execute them confidently during online matches.

  • Mix it Up: Combine feints with changes in pace and direction to keep opponents guessing and create unpredictability in your attacking play.

  • Read the Defense: Pay attention to how defenders react to your feints. Adjust your approach based on their positioning and tendencies to exploit their vulnerabilities.

  • Timing: Use feints and skill moves at the right moment. Timing is crucial for maximizing their effectiveness and creating scoring opportunities.

Conclusion

Mastering these top three feints in FIFA—La Croqueta, Elastico, and Drag Back—can give you a significant advantage in matches by helping you beat defenders, create space, and score goals. Incorporate these skill moves into your gameplay repertoire, practice consistently, and adapt them to different match situations to increase your chances of winning games in FIFA.

column3: How to Choose the Right Players for Your Team in FIFA
column5:
Building a successful team in FIFA involves selecting players who complement your preferred playstyle, fit into your chosen formation, and enhance your overall squad performance. Here’s a step-by-step guide on how to choose the right players for your team:

1. Identify Your Playstyle

  • Offensive or Defensive: Determine whether you prefer an attacking or defensive playstyle. This will influence the types of players you prioritize in your team selection.

  • Formation: Choose a formation that suits your playstyle and tactical preferences. Different formations require specific player attributes and roles to function effectively.

2. Player Attributes and Positions

  • Key Attributes: Identify the essential attributes for each position in your chosen formation. For example, pace and dribbling are crucial for wingers, while defending and physicality are vital for central defenders.

  • Role-Specific Qualities: Assess how each player’s attributes align with their designated role within the team. Consider factors such as passing accuracy for midfielders, shooting ability for forwards, and defensive capabilities for defenders.

3. Chemistry and Links

  • Chemistry Style: Utilize Chemistry Styles (e.g., Shadow, Hunter, Catalyst) to enhance specific attributes of your players and optimize their performance in matches.

  • Chemistry Links: Build strong chemistry links between players by selecting those from the same league, club, or nationality. This boosts their chemistry level and improves their on-field cohesion.
column7:
4. Budget Management

  • Market Analysis: Research player prices and market trends to maximize your budget. Balance quality and cost-effectiveness when purchasing players for your team.

  • Invest Wisely: Prioritize investments in key positions that significantly impact your team’s performance. Allocate resources based on the importance of each position within your tactical setup.

5. Scouting and Player Reviews

  • Scout Players: Use scouting tools and resources within FIFA to identify potential transfer targets. Consider player ratings, reviews, and community feedback to make informed decisions.

  • Trial and Evaluation: Test potential additions to your squad in single-player matches or friendlies to assess how well they integrate into your team’s dynamics and perform in different scenarios.

6. Team Balance and Depth

  • Balanced Squad: Ensure your team has a balanced mix of attacking prowess, defensive solidity, and midfield control. Avoid overloading in one area at the expense of others.

  • Depth: Build a squad with sufficient depth to handle injuries, suspensions, and fixture congestion. Have reliable substitutes and rotation options to maintain performance levels throughout the season.

7. Adaptability and Flexibility

  • Tactical Adjustments: Choose players who offer versatility and can adapt to different roles or formations if needed. This flexibility allows you to adjust tactics and strategies based on opponent strengths and weaknesses.

Conclusion

Selecting the right players for your FIFA team involves careful consideration of playstyle, player attributes, chemistry, budget management, and tactical flexibility. By following these steps and continuously refining your squad based on performance and feedback, you can build a cohesive and competitive team capable of achieving success in FIFA matches. Remember to prioritize teamwork and player synergy to maximize overall team performance and enjoyment of the game.

column3: How to Call Players and Make Forward Runs in FIFA
column5:
Calling players to make forward runs and off-the-ball movements is essential for creating attacking opportunities and breaking down stubborn defenses in FIFA. Here’s a guide on how to effectively call players and execute forward runs:

1. Calling Players to Receive the Ball

  • Player Lock: Press the L1/LB button to call a specific player to come closer and receive a pass. This is useful when you want to involve a particular player in the build-up play.

  • Trigger Runs: Use the L1/LB button to trigger off-the-ball runs for nearby teammates. Hold L1/LB and flick the right analog stick (RS) in the direction you want the player to make their run (e.g., forward, diagonally, wide).

2. Timing and Direction

  • Anticipation: Anticipate when and where you want players to make forward runs. This can be based on openings in the opponent's defense or to exploit gaps created by your own teammates' movements.

  • Directional Control: Use the right analog stick (RS) to manually control the direction of the run after triggering it with L1/LB. Direct runs towards open space or away from marking defenders to create passing options.
column7:
3. Combining Calls and Movement

  • One-Two Passes: Execute one-two passes (L1/LB + X/A) to initiate quick passing combinations and create opportunities for forward runs. Use this technique to bypass defenders and advance towards the goal.

  • Overlap and Underlap: Instruct full-backs or midfielders to overlap (L1/LB + RS towards the wing) or underlap (L1/LB + RS towards the center) to provide width or support in attack, respectively.

4. Utilizing Tactics and Instructions

  • Custom Tactics: Set custom tactics in your team management settings to encourage players to make more runs or prioritize specific types of attacking movements (e.g., fast build-up play, counter-attacks).

  • Player Instructions: Adjust individual player instructions to dictate their attacking behaviors. For example, instruct strikers to stay central, drift wide, or make runs behind the defense based on their strengths and your tactical approach.

5. Practice and Adaptation

  • Skill Games: Use skill games and training modes in FIFA to practice calling players and executing forward runs in controlled environments. Focus on timing, precision, and awareness of space.

  • Match Experience: Apply what you’ve practiced in actual matches to refine your ability to call players and make effective forward runs under pressure and in dynamic game situations.

6. Communication and Coordination

  • Team Understanding: Develop an understanding with teammates through regular play and communication. Coordinate with AI teammates and react to human-controlled teammates' movements to maximize attacking opportunities.

Conclusion

Mastering the art of calling players and making forward runs in FIFA requires anticipation, timing, and effective use of game mechanics. By using L1/LB to call players and trigger runs, combined with directional control and tactical adjustments, you can create dynamic attacking movements that unsettle defenses and lead to scoring opportunities. Practice consistently, adapt your strategies based on match scenarios, and develop a cohesive attacking approach to elevate your gameplay in FIFA.

column3: How to Kick Properly and in What Situations in FIFA
column5:
Kicking properly in FIFA involves understanding different types of kicks and knowing when to use them based on the game situation. Here’s a guide to mastering kicks and their applications:

1. Basic Kicks

  • Passing (X/A button): Use short passes (tap X/A) for quick and accurate passes to nearby teammates. This is effective for maintaining possession and building up play.

  • Through Balls (Triangle/Y button): Execute through balls (hold Triangle/Y) to send teammates into space behind the defense. Use this when a teammate is making a run and you want to play them through on goal.

  • Shooting (Circle/B button): Shoot with power (tap Circle/B) when taking a shot on goal. Adjust the power using the shot meter for optimal accuracy and to beat the goalkeeper.

2. Advanced Techniques

  • Finesse Shots: Perform finesse shots (hold R1/RB + tap Circle/B) when shooting from a narrow angle or when you want to curl the ball around the goalkeeper. Finesse shots are effective for placing the ball into the far corners of the net.

  • Chip Shots: Use chip shots (Lob/Cross button) when the goalkeeper rushes out or when you want to lift the ball over a diving goalkeeper. Tap the button lightly for a delicate chip or hold it longer for a higher trajectory.

  • Driven Shots: Execute driven shots (hold L1/LB + tap Circle/B) for low, powerful shots that are harder for goalkeepers to save. Use driven shots when shooting from close range or when you want to keep the ball low and on target.
column7:
3. Situational Kicking

  • Building from the Back: Use short passes (X/A button) when building up play from your own defense. This helps maintain possession and move the ball into midfield.

  • Counter-Attacks: Opt for through balls (Triangle/Y button) during counter-attacks to exploit spaces left by opponents pushing forward. Time the through ball to release your teammate behind the defense.

  • Finishing Moves: Use shooting techniques (Circle/B button) when in shooting positions near the opponent's goal. Adjust your shot type (finesse, driven) based on the goalkeeper's positioning and the angle of your shot.

4. Set Pieces

  • Free Kicks: Master free kick techniques (L1/LB + Circle/B) for direct shots or crosses into the box. Adjust power and curve to evade the wall and beat the goalkeeper.

  • Penalty Kicks: Aim penalties (L1/LB + Left Stick) to place shots in corners or powerfully strike them past the goalkeeper. Use deception (R2/RT) to fake your shot before taking it.

5. Practice and Mastery

  • Skill Games: Utilize FIFA's skill games to practice different types of kicks and hone your accuracy and timing.

  • Match Experience: Apply what you've learned in actual matches to adapt your kicking technique to various game situations, such as close-range finishes, long-range shots, and set pieces.

6. Adaptability and Strategy

  • Game Situation: Assess the game situation, including scoreline, time remaining, and opponent's defensive setup, to choose the appropriate kick. Adapt your strategy based on whether you need to score, maintain possession, or defend a lead.

Conclusion

Mastering how to kick properly in FIFA involves understanding the nuances of each kick type and knowing when to execute them based on the dynamics of the match. Practice consistently, experiment with different techniques in various game situations, and refine your kicking skills to become a more proficient player in FIFA. By mastering these techniques, you can improve your goal-scoring ability, enhance your passing accuracy, and effectively manage different phases of gameplay.

column3: How to Properly Start an Attack in FIFA
column5:
Starting an attack effectively in FIFA requires a combination of tactical awareness, player positioning, and precise passing to transition from defense to offense swiftly. Here’s a comprehensive guide on how to initiate and execute attacks in FIFA:

1. Build-Up from Defense

  • Patient Build-Up: Use short passes (X/A button) to circulate the ball among defenders and midfielders. Maintain possession while assessing passing lanes and waiting for opportunities to advance.

  • Use of Goalkeeper: Utilize the goalkeeper to initiate attacks by throwing (Triangle/Y button) or kicking (Square/X button) the ball to open teammates. This can bypass the opponent's first line of defense and start quick counter-attacks.

2. Midfield Transition

  • Progressive Passing: Move the ball forward through midfield using short and medium-range passes (X/A button). Look for gaps in the opponent’s midfield and defensive lines to exploit with through balls (Triangle/Y button) or dribbling.

  • Player Movement: Encourage forward runs (L1/LB button + Right Stick) from midfielders and wingers to create passing options and stretch the opponent's defense.

3. Exploiting Wings and Flanks

  • Wing Play: Utilize your full-backs and wingers to attack down the wings. Use overlapping runs (L1/LB button + Right Stick) to overlap and create width, allowing for crosses into the penalty area.

  • Crossing Opportunities: Deliver crosses (Square/X button) into the box when your wingers or full-backs have advanced into crossing positions. Target teammates making runs towards the goal or waiting at the far post.
column7:
4. Counter-Attacking

  • Quick Transitions: Capitalize on turnovers and counter-attack opportunities by quickly transitioning from defense to attack. Use through balls (Triangle/Y button) to release fast strikers behind the opponent’s defense.

  • Direct Play: Opt for direct passes and long balls (Triangle/Y button or Square/X button) to exploit spaces left by opponents committing players forward. This can catch defenders out of position and create goal-scoring chances.

5. Set Pieces and Dead-Ball Situations

  • Free Kicks: Take advantage of free kicks (L1/LB + Circle/B button) to initiate attacks with direct shots or by playing short passes to teammates in scoring positions.

  • Corner Kicks: Strategically position players in the box and utilize different corner kick tactics (D-pad commands) to create scoring opportunities from crosses or short corners.

6. Game Intelligence and Adaptation

  • Reading the Game: Analyze the opponent’s defensive setup and adjust your attacking strategy accordingly. Exploit weaknesses in their formation, defensive gaps, or tired legs as the match progresses.

  • Patience and Composure: Remain patient when building attacks, especially against defensively organized opponents. Avoid forcing passes or shots that could lead to turnovers and counter-attacks.

7. Practice and Execution

  • Skill Games: Use FIFA’s skill games and training modes to practice different attacking techniques, passing accuracy, and finishing under pressure.

  • Match Experience: Apply what you’ve learned in actual matches to refine your attacking approach and adapt to various game situations, such as leading, trailing, or seeking an equalizer.

Conclusion

Starting an attack effectively in FIFA requires a blend of strategic thinking, technical proficiency, and awareness of game dynamics. By mastering these techniques and principles — such as patient build-up play, exploiting wing play, quick transitions, and set-piece strategies — you can create more scoring opportunities and increase your chances of success in FIFA matches. Continuously practice and adapt your attacking strategy based on opponent tendencies and match scenarios to become a more formidable attacking force in the game.

column3: How to Score from Corner Kicks in FIFA
column5:
Scoring from corner kicks in FIFA can be a potent weapon if executed correctly. Here’s a detailed guide on how to effectively score from corner kicks:

1. Taking the Corner Kick

  • Player Selection: Choose a player with good crossing and curve attributes to take the corner kick. This player should ideally have high stats in crossing accuracy and curve to deliver precise crosses into the box.

  • Positioning: Position the aiming reticle (Left Stick) where you want the ball to be delivered into the penalty area. Aim for areas where your teammates are making runs or where you anticipate creating a goal-scoring opportunity.

2. Delivery Techniques

  • Normal Cross (Square/X button): Use a normal cross for a standard delivery into the penalty area. Adjust the power and trajectory based on the movement of your teammates and the positioning of defenders.

  • Low Cross (Double tap Square/X button): Opt for a low cross when aiming for teammates near the near post or making runs towards the edge of the six-yard box. This can catch defenders off guard and create close-range scoring chances.

  • Driven Cross (L1/LB + Square/X button): Execute a driven cross for a fast and powerful delivery into the box. This is effective when targeting teammates in crowded penalty areas or when trying to beat defenders to the ball.
column7:
3. Player Movement and Positioning

  • Near Post Runs: Instruct players to make runs towards the near post by using the attacking tactics (D-pad commands) or manually triggering runs (L1/LB + Right Stick). Aim crosses towards these runners to create flick-on opportunities or direct shots.

  • Far Post Targeting: Target taller players or those with good heading accuracy at the far post. Use lofted crosses or driven crosses to reach these players, aiming for headers towards the goal or knockdowns to oncoming teammates.

4. Attacking the Ball

  • Timing: Time your player's jump (Circle/B button) to meet the incoming cross at its highest point. This increases the chances of winning aerial duels against defenders and directing headers towards goal.

  • Positioning: Position your player in space between defenders or at the edge of the six-yard box to maximize their heading or shooting opportunities. Anticipate the flight of the ball and adjust positioning accordingly.

5. Variety and Tactics

  • Set-Piece Tactics: Customize your set-piece tactics (D-pad commands) to instruct players to attack the ball aggressively or to position themselves for knockdowns and second-chance opportunities.

  • Short Corners: Occasionally use short corners (L1/LB button) to create space for crosses or to draw defenders out of position before delivering the ball into the box. This can catch opponents off guard and create openings for shots on goal.

6. Practice and Adaptation

  • Skill Games: Utilize FIFA's skill games and training modes to practice different corner kick techniques, aiming accuracy, and player positioning.

  • Match Experience: Apply what you’ve practiced in actual matches to refine your corner kick strategy and adapt to opponent tactics and defensive setups.

Conclusion

Scoring from corner kicks in FIFA requires precision in delivery, effective player movement, and timing in aerial challenges. By mastering these techniques and principles—such as selecting the right delivery type, targeting players in scoring positions, and utilizing set-piece tactics—you can increase your team's scoring opportunities from corner kicks and enhance your overall attacking effectiveness in the game. Continuously practice and adapt your corner kick strategy based on match scenarios and opponent tendencies to maximize your chances of success.

column3: How to Score Free Kicks in FIFA
column5:
Scoring from free kicks in FIFA requires skill, precision, and understanding of various techniques. Here’s a comprehensive guide on how to effectively score free kicks in the game:

1. Selecting the Right Kicker

  • Player Attributes: Choose a player with high Free Kick Accuracy (FK Accuracy) and Curve stats. Players like Messi, Ronaldo, or specialist free kick takers in your team are ideal choices.

  • Positioning: Position the kicker based on the angle and distance from the goal. Adjust the aiming reticle (Left Stick) to target specific areas of the goal or to avoid the defensive wall.

2. Executing the Free Kick

  • Shot Power: Hold down the shoot button (Circle/B button) to determine the power of the shot. The longer you hold it, the more power the shot will have. Adjust the power based on the distance from the goal and the trajectory needed.

  • Aiming: Adjust the direction of the shot with the aiming reticle (Left Stick). Aim for corners of the goal where the goalkeeper is less likely to reach, or aim to curl the ball around the wall.
column7:
3. Types of Free Kicks

  • Power Free Kick: Hold the shoot button (Circle/B button) for a powerful shot aimed directly at goal. This is effective for long-range attempts or when the wall is not well positioned.

  • Curled Free Kick: Use the right analog stick (RS) to apply curl to the shot. This is done by flicking the RS in the direction you want the ball to curl. Curled free kicks are effective for placing the ball around the wall and into the top corners of the goal.

  • Driven Free Kick: Hold L1/LB while pressing the shoot button (Circle/B button) for a driven shot. Driven free kicks are powerful and low, designed to beat the goalkeeper with pace rather than finesse.

4. Set-Up and Tactics

  • Wall Positioning: Use the free kick camera (L1/LB button) to adjust your view and see where the wall is positioned. Look for gaps or weaknesses in the wall that you can exploit with your shot.

  • Decoy Runners: Use players to distract the goalkeeper or move the wall by making decoy runs (L2/LT button). This can create openings for your shot or confuse the defensive setup.

5. Advanced Techniques

  • Knuckleball Free Kick: For advanced players, hold L1/LB + R1/RB while powering up the shot (Circle/B button) to execute a knuckleball free kick. This shot has unpredictable movement in the air, making it difficult for goalkeepers to save.

  • Dipping Free Kick: Aim for the top corner of the goal and hold L2/LT while powering up the shot (Circle/B button). This adds backspin to the ball, causing it to dip suddenly as it approaches the goal.

6. Practice and Mastery

  • Skill Games: Use the free kick skill games and practice modes in FIFA to improve your technique, accuracy, and consistency in scoring free kicks.

  • Match Experience: Apply what you’ve learned in actual matches to adjust your free kick strategy based on goalkeeper positioning, wall setup, and match circumstances.

Conclusion

Scoring from free kicks in FIFA requires practice, patience, and mastery of different techniques. By selecting the right kicker, understanding shot power and aiming mechanics, utilizing set-piece tactics, and practicing consistently, you can increase your chances of scoring spectacular goals from free kicks in the game. Continuously refine your skills and adapt your strategy based on match situations and opponent tactics to become a more proficient free kick taker in FIFA.

column3: How to Score Every Penalty in FIFA
column5:
Scoring penalties in FIFA requires a combination of precision, timing, and understanding of goalkeeper tendencies. Here’s a comprehensive guide on how to effectively score penalties in the game:

1. Preparation and Player Selection

  • Penalty Taker: Choose a player with high Penalty Taking attribute (Pen) for better chances of success. Players like Messi, Ronaldo, or designated penalty specialists in your team are ideal choices.

  • Approach: Position your kicker using the aiming reticle (Left Stick). Aim for corners of the goal where the goalkeeper is less likely to reach, or aim to deceive the goalkeeper with shot placement.

2. Executing the Penalty

  • Power and Accuracy: Hold down the shoot button (Circle/B button) to determine the power and height of the shot. The longer you hold it, the more power the shot will have. Aim for the corners of the goal to make it harder for the goalkeeper to save.

  • Shot Placement: Adjust the direction of the shot with the aiming reticle (Left Stick). Aim for the side-netting or just inside the post to increase the chance of scoring.
column7:
3. Types of Penalty Kicks

  • Normal Shot: Hold the shoot button (Circle/B button) for a standard shot aimed directly at goal. This is effective for placing the ball in a specific corner away from the goalkeeper’s reach.

  • Chip Shot: Hold the Lob/Cross button (L1/LB) and then tap the shoot button (Circle/B button) for a chip shot. Use this technique when the goalkeeper dives early or moves towards one side, leaving the top of the net exposed.

  • Feint: Perform a feint by tapping the shoot button (Circle/B button) twice quickly. This can trick the goalkeeper into diving early or the wrong way, giving you an open goal to shoot at.

4. Mind Games and Deception

  • Decoy Movement: Move your kicker slightly to one side during the run-up using the Left Stick to influence the goalkeeper's dive direction. This can create openings in the goal to exploit.

  • Wait for the Keeper: Delay your shot to see if the goalkeeper commits to a side. Adjust your aim at the last moment to shoot in the opposite direction of the goalkeeper's dive.

5. Practice and Mastery

  • Skill Games: Utilize penalty kick practice modes in FIFA to improve your timing, shot placement, and ability to read the goalkeeper's movements.

  • Match Experience: Apply what you’ve learned in actual matches to adjust your penalty-taking strategy based on goalkeeper tendencies, match circumstances, and pressure situations.

Conclusion

Scoring penalties in FIFA requires practice, patience, and strategic execution. By selecting the right kicker, mastering shot power and accuracy, utilizing feints and chip shots, and understanding goalkeeper tendencies, you can increase your chances of converting penalties into goals in the game. Continuously refine your skills and adapt your strategy based on match situations and opponent tactics to become a more proficient penalty taker in FIFA.

column3: What Celebrations Should You Use to Piss Off Your Opponent?
column5:
In FIFA, celebrations can be a way to express victory or to potentially unsettle your opponent. Here are some celebrations that players often use to provoke or annoy their opponents:

1. Shush Celebration

  • Execution: Hold the right analog stick down (on consoles) to perform the "Shush" celebration.

  • Effect: This celebration involves putting a finger to your lips as if shushing the crowd. It's often used to taunt opponents and show dominance.

2. A-OK Celebration

  • Execution: Hold the right analog stick left (on consoles).

  • Effect: This celebration includes putting your thumb and forefinger together to form a circle and placing it around your eye, which can be perceived as mocking or dismissive.
column7:
3. Cell Phone Celebration

  • Execution: Hold the right analog stick up (on consoles).

  • Effect: This celebration involves pretending to make a phone call with your hand, which some players find disrespectful or irritating.

4. Dead Fish Celebration

  • Execution: Hold the right analog stick down (on consoles) twice.

  • Effect: This celebration involves flopping on the ground like a dead fish, which can be seen as unsportsmanlike or mocking.

5. Waddle Walk Celebration

  • Execution: Hold the right analog stick right (on consoles).

  • Effect: This celebration imitates a duck's waddling walk, which some opponents may find irritating due to its playful and possibly condescending nature.

Considerations

  • Respect: While celebrations can be a part of the game's fun and competitive spirit, it's important to use them responsibly and avoid excessively taunting or disrespecting opponents.

  • Personal Style: Ultimately, the choice of celebration depends on personal preference and the dynamics of the match. Using celebrations sparingly and in good spirit can contribute positively to the enjoyment of the game for both players.

Conclusion

Celebrations in FIFA can serve various purposes, from expressing joy to potentially aggravating opponents. When choosing celebrations with the intention to annoy, it's essential to consider sportsmanship and respect for your opponent. By understanding the impact of different celebrations, players can use them tactically while maintaining the spirit of fair play and enjoyment of the game.

column3: Why It Is Important to Learn How to Use Timed Finishing
column5:
Learning how to use timed finishing effectively in FIFA can significantly enhance your goal-scoring ability and overall gameplay. Here are several reasons why mastering timed finishing is important:

1. Increased Shooting Accuracy

  • Timing Precision: Timed finishing allows you to control the accuracy and power of your shots more precisely. By hitting the shoot button (Circle/B button) a second time at the right moment, indicated by a green or red timing indicator, you can increase the chances of your shot being on target and more difficult for the goalkeeper to save.

  • Goal-Scoring Opportunities: Properly timed shots are more likely to result in goals, especially when shooting from difficult angles or under pressure from defenders. This can lead to more successful attacks and higher scoring matches.

2. Enhanced Shot Power

  • Power Boost: Timed finishing also affects the power of your shots. If timed correctly, your shots will have a noticeable increase in power, making them harder for goalkeepers to save even from longer distances.

  • Long-Range Shooting: Effective use of timed finishing allows you to attempt and score from longer ranges with more confidence, as the increased power helps the ball travel faster towards the goal.
column7:
3. Versatility in Attack

  • Variety of Shot Types: Timed finishing can be applied to different shot techniques such as finesse shots, driven shots, volleys, and headers. This versatility allows you to adapt your shooting style based on the situation and positioning of defenders and the goalkeeper.

  • Creative Play: Mastering timed finishing enables you to execute more creative and skillful shots, including curling shots around defenders or chipping the ball over a rushing goalkeeper.

4. Competitive Edge

  • Skill Differential: In competitive FIFA play, players who have mastered timed finishing have a distinct advantage over those who rely solely on basic shooting mechanics. This skill can be crucial in tournaments and online matches where every goal counts.

  • Adaptation to Gameplay Updates: FIFA games often receive updates and patches that can adjust shooting mechanics. Players who understand and practice timed finishing can more easily adapt to these changes and maintain their scoring proficiency.

5. Learning Curve and Improvement

  • Skill Development: Learning how to use timed finishing effectively requires practice and understanding of timing cues. As you improve your timing and execution, you'll notice gradual improvements in your shooting accuracy and goal-scoring consistency.

  • Feedback Mechanism: FIFA provides visual and auditory feedback on timed finishing attempts, helping you to learn and refine your technique over time. Use this feedback to adjust your timing and improve your overall shooting proficiency.

Conclusion

Mastering timed finishing in FIFA is essential for enhancing shooting accuracy, increasing shot power, and adding versatility to your attacking gameplay. By practicing and understanding the mechanics of timed finishing, you can elevate your goal-scoring capabilities and gain a competitive edge in matches. Continuously refine your timing and adapt your shooting strategy to different in-game situations to maximize your effectiveness on the virtual pitch.

column3: Why It Is Important to Use the Right Stick Properly
column5:
Using the right stick properly in FIFA is crucial for executing advanced moves, maintaining control over players' movements, and enhancing overall gameplay effectiveness. Here’s why mastering the right stick is important:

1. Player Dribbling and Skill Moves

  • Skill Moves: The right stick (RS) allows you to perform a wide range of skill moves such as step-overs, ball rolls, drag backs, and heel-to-heel flicks. These moves are essential for beating defenders, creating space, and advancing the ball up the field effectively.

  • Dribbling Control: By manipulating the right stick, you can control the pace and direction of dribbling. Quick flicks and changes in direction can help you evade defenders and maintain possession in tight spaces.

2. Enhanced Player Control

  • 360° Movement: The right stick enables you to move players in any direction, providing precise control over their positioning on the field. This is crucial for positioning defenders, making runs with attackers, and intercepting passes or crosses.

  • Close Control: Using small movements with the right stick allows you to keep the ball close to your player’s feet, making it harder for defenders to tackle and increasing your ability to maneuver in congested areas.
column7:
3. Defensive Tactics

  • Jockeying: When defending, the right stick is used for jockeying (holding L2/LT) and making subtle adjustments to stay close to the attacker. This helps in maintaining defensive shape and timing tackles effectively.

  • Tackling and Interceptions: By using the right stick to position defenders and anticipate passes, you can improve your chances of making interceptions and winning possession back quickly.

4. Shooting and Passing

  • Shooting Angles: Adjusting the right stick while shooting allows for more precise aiming. You can curl shots around goalkeepers or place them into specific corners of the net, increasing your scoring opportunities.

  • Passing Accuracy: In combination with the left stick, the right stick can be used for manual passing. This gives you more control over the direction and weight of your passes, enabling more accurate distribution of the ball.

5. Advanced Techniques and Creativity

  • Flicks and Chips: Mastering the right stick allows you to perform flicks and chips to lob the ball over defenders or deliver precise passes into space for teammates. These techniques are useful for initiating attacks and creating goal-scoring opportunities.
